Accidental Release Prevention 

SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant has developed a Risk Management Program and an Emergency Response Plan to address CalARP Program requirements (19 CCR ?2735-2785).  

SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the chlorination and the ammonia injection systems.  SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

The SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant is located at 18535 Aliso Canyon Road, 

Rancho Santa Fe, California. 92067.

The regulated substances at the Facility are:

?    Chlorine.  This regulated substance is used in their chlorination system for final effluent disinfection.  The chlorination system consists of a gaseous chlorine storage and feed system.  The gaseous chlorine is housed in the chlorine storage room.  The storage room contains eight scales, each configured with four one-ton chlorine cylinders, for a total of eight one-ton cylinders.  However, only four cylinders are utilized simultaneously, while the additional four are on stand-by.  A total of up to eight gaseous chlorine one-ton cylinders are located on site at any given time.

?    30% aqueous ammonia. This regulated substance is used in their aqueous ammonia system consists of a liquid storage tank (T-10) outfitted with pressure relief valves containing 30% aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide) solution.  Rather than using a metering pump, compressed air is supplied to the storage tank to maintain a slight positive pressure.  The aqueous ammonia is then fed at a small rate to the T.M. Vault Drip Line, F.M. Chamber Drip Line, and FCW Drip Line.

?Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Per CalARP Regulations and EPA RMP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for each covered process at the Facility.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the 2014 Five Year Update Binder.

?Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:

An alternative release scenario was modeled for each covered process at the Facility.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the 2014 Five Year Update Binder.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of chlorine and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release, including the following:

?    Ammonia and chlorine sensors are located in the process areas.

?    Gas detection is in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs.

?    The covered processes have alarms and interlocks.

?    Automatic/Manual shutdowns are in place.

?    P

ersonal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by plant personnel, as necessary.

?    The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

?    The history of the SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant facility (i.e., no CalARP-applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating both covered processes.



Accidental Release Prevention Program 



Process No.1:  Chlorination System using the regulated substance; chlorine 

The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 48,000 pounds of gaseous chlorine. 

MAXIMUM INTENDED INVENTORY

(Chlorine)

Note: A 1-ton container of chlorine will contain at a maximum 2,000 pounds.

Primary 1-ton Containers    8,000 pounds (4 Containers)

Standby 1- ton Containers    8,000 pounds (4 Containers)

Storage 1-ton Containers    0 pounds (0 Containers)

Maximum Feeding Inventory    16,000 pounds (8 Containers)

Maximum Intended Inventory    48,000 pounds (24 Containers)



As illustrated in the table above, the facility has a maximum intended inventory of 48,000 pounds (lbs.) of chlorine on-site.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 2,500-lbs threshold quantity for US EPA RMP and the 1,500-lbs threshold quantity for Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities, and over the 100-lbs state threshold for CalARP Program.  As a result, the chlorine covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, US EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

As illustrated in the table above, the facility has a maximum intended inventory of 22,400 pounds (lbs.) of ammonia on-site.  Therefore, it is over the 20,000-lb. threshold (20% or greater concentration) for US EPA RMP and the 500-lb. (all concentrations) state threshold for CalARP Program.  SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant is not subject to Cal/OSHA PSM or Program 3 requirements due to the fact that the concentration of aqueous ammonia managed at the facility is 30% and the Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities of aqueous ammonia is only for concentrations greater than 44%.  For the reasons mentioned above, the SCR Ammonia System is subject to CalARP Program Level 2 and US EPA RMP Program Level 2.

Five-Year Accident History 

New accident history information - For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR ?2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under 19 CCR ?2745.5, ?2745.6, and ?2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under 19 CCR ?2745.10, whichever is earlier.

From 19 CCR

?2750.9: 

The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of ammonia at SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program

SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant has filed a Unified Contingency Plan with San Diego County Department of Environmental Health.  This plan provides the response protocols and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine and ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which have been implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This plan includes:



?Emergency Alarm Procedures

?Evacuation Procedures

?Safety and Health Considerations

?Notification Procedure



In addition, the SFID - R.E. Badger Filtration Plant is a First Responder Facility.  The Facility has implemented an Emergency Response Plan and it can be located with the Safety Officer, Rocky A. Hughes.  The Facility is trained and fully equipped to respond to hazardous material releases.
